Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

type: Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0}
name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

type: ¬BddAbove {p | p.Prime}
name: Nat.not_bddAbove_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime numbers is unbounded.

This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ p.Prime
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString: This is Euclid's theorem on the infinitude of primes. The theorem states that for every natural number `n`, there exists a prime number `p` such that `p` is greater than or equal to `n`. In other words, there are infinitely many prime numbers, and for any given natural number, there will always be a prime number that is greater than or equal to that number.

The sum over the reciprocals of the primes diverges.

type: ¬Summable (Set.indicator {p | Nat.Prime p} fun n => 1 / ↑n)
name: not_summable_one_div_on_primes
docString: The sum over the reciprocals of the primes diverges.

The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

type: {p | p.Prime}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime
docString: The set of prime natural numbers is infinite.

This theorem states that for any natural number `b` that is greater than or equal to 1, the set of natural numbers `n` that are Fermat pseudoprimes to the base `b` is infinite. In other words, there are infinitely many natural numbers `n` that satisfy Fermat's Little Theorem for a specific `b`, but are not actually prime numbers.

type: ∀ {b : ℕ}, 1 ≤ b → {n | n.FermatPsp b}.Infinite
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_pseudoprimes
docString: This theorem states that for any natural number `b` that is greater than or equal to 1, the set of natural numbers `n` that are Fermat pseudoprimes to the base `b` is infinite. In other words, there are infinitely many natural numbers `n` that satisfy Fermat's Little Theorem for a specific `b`, but are not actually prime numbers.

The type of prime numbers

type: Type
name: Nat.Primes
docString: The type of prime numbers

For any positive `k : ℕ` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`.

type: ∀ {k : ℕ}, k ≠ 0 → Set.Infinite {p | Nat.Prime p ∧ p ≡ 1 [MOD k]}
name: Nat.infinite_setOf_prime_modEq_one
docString: For any positive `k : ℕ` there are infinitely many primes `p` such that `p ≡ 1 [MOD k]`.

**Lifting the exponent lemma** for odd primes.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ},
  Nat.Prime p →
    Odd p →
      ∀ {x y : ℤ},
        ↑p ∣ x - y →
          ¬↑p ∣ x → ∀ (n : ℕ), multiplicity (↑p) (x ^ n - y ^ n) = multiplicity (↑p) (x - y) + multiplicity p n
name: multiplicity.Int.pow_sub_pow
docString: **Lifting the exponent lemma** for odd primes.

Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

type: (s : Set ℕ) → [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ s] → [inst : Infinite ↑s] → Denumerable ↑s
name: Nat.Subtype.denumerable
docString: Any infinite set of naturals is denumerable.

Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), ∃ p, n ≤ p ∧ Nat.Prime p
name: Nat.exists_infinite_primes
docString:
Euclid's theorem on the **infinitude of primes**.
Here given in the form: for every `n`, there exists a prime number `p ≥ n`.

To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.

type: (∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → Odd p → FermatLastTheoremFor p) → FermatLastTheorem
name: FermatLastTheorem.of_odd_primes
docString: To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.

The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [dec_irr : (p : Associates α) → Decidable (Irreducible p)]
  [inst_1 : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] [dec : DecidableEq α] [dec' : DecidableEq (Associates α)] {a p : Associates α},
  Irreducible p →
    ∀ [inst_2 : (n : ℕ) → Decidable (a ∣ p ^ n)] {n : ℕ} (h : a ∣ p ^ n),
      a = p ^ Nat.find (_ : ∃ n, (fun n => a ∣ p ^ n) n)
name: Associates.eq_pow_find_of_dvd_irreducible_pow
docString: The only divisors of prime powers are prime powers.

Noncomputably determines the multiset of prime factors.

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] →
    [inst_1 : DecidableEq α] → [inst_2 : NormalizationMonoid α] → [inst : UniqueFactorizationMonoid α] → α → Multiset α
name: UniqueFactorizationMonoid.normalizedFactors
docString: Noncomputably determines the multiset of prime factors.

There is an infinite base

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} {M : Matroid α} [self : Matroid.InfiniteRk M], ∃ B, M.Base B ∧ Set.Infinite B
name: Matroid.InfiniteRk.exists_infinite_base
docString: There is an infinite base

The prime factors of a natural number as a finset.

type: ℕ → Finset ℕ
name: Nat.primeFactors
docString: The prime factors of a natural number as a finset.

The multiset consisting of a single prime

type: Nat.Primes → PrimeMultiset
name: PrimeMultiset.ofPrime
docString: The multiset consisting of a single prime

A finite field has prime power cardinality.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype α] [inst_1 : Field α], IsPrimePow (Fintype.card α)
name: Fintype.isPrimePow_card_of_field
docString: A finite field has prime power cardinality.

Positive integers biject with multisets of primes.

type: ℕ+ ≃ PrimeMultiset
name: PNat.factorMultisetEquiv
docString: Positive integers biject with multisets of primes.

The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1`

type: ∀ (n : ℕ), Nat.factorization n = 0 ↔ n = 0 ∨ n = 1
name: Nat.factorization_eq_zero_iff'
docString: The only numbers with empty prime factorization are `0` and `1`

We relate a finite product over primes to an infinite sum over smooth numbers.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : NormedCommRing R] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace R] {f : ℕ → R},
  f 1 = 1 →
    (∀ {m n : ℕ}, Nat.Coprime m n → f (m * n) = f m * f n) →
      (∀ {p : ℕ}, Nat.Prime p → Summable fun n => ‖f (p ^ n)‖) →
        ∀ (N : ℕ),
          (Summable fun m => ‖f ↑m‖) ∧
            HasSum (fun m => f ↑m) (Finset.prod (Nat.primesBelow N) fun p => ∑' (n : ℕ), f (p ^ n))
name: EulerProduct.summable_and_hasSum_smoothNumbers_prod_primesBelow_tsum
docString: We relate a finite product over primes to an infinite sum over smooth numbers.

A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

type: ∀ {α : Type u} [inst : Group α] [inst_1 : Fintype α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Fintype.card α = p → IsCyclic α
name: isCyclic_of_prime_card
docString: A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

The finset of those partitions in which every part is odd.

type: (n : ℕ) → Finset (Nat.Partition n)
name: Nat.Partition.odds
docString: The finset of those partitions in which every part is odd.

The maximal sieve always exists.

type: {C : Type u₁} → [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v₁, u₁} C] → {X : C} → Inhabited (CategoryTheory.Sieve X)
name: CategoryTheory.Sieve.sieveInhabited
docString: The maximal sieve always exists.
